ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really can't say I learned anything in this class.
Knowledge of networks; matrix math; Bayesian theory; Gephi
I learned to analyze networks of many different groups and also how to use the Gephi platform.
Learned about networks
I learned a great amount about networks and game theory
I learned how to use gephi and a better understanding of some mathematical concepts related to networks.
I developed my ability to work with online programs. I also developed presentation skills and teamwork.
I learned about the structure of networks
Learning how to make networks in Gephi.
This course teaches basically nothing as it required basically nothing of its students. If you really wanted to learn, you could go to class and take notes but no one does.
I learned about how networks work

I got a greater insight into how math and probability affects our everyday lives, and found the knowledge gained regarding probabilities especially useful. It was also great at developing group project skills
intro to gephi, networks
Very few. I was reminded about how to do some basic addition and multiplication  and about what networks are and how they can work.

I learned how to calculate 2 by 2 transition probabilities to solve for a desired probability applied to real-world occurrences and problems like the probability of weather or markets, for example. I learned how to calculate probabilities from contingency tables applied to real-word examples like going to an amusement park, for example. Furthermore, I learned how to determine nash equilibrium, and solve other game theory problems. And, I also learned how to solve problems related to general strategy to zero sum games, applied to a real-world example of Venus and Serena Williams.

Better understanding of some basic topics such as probability, game theory, and working with matrices. Also gained the opportunity to work on a project that interested me and enabled me to put into practice some of the topics we learned about in class.
Exactly what you think of this class.
I developed insight into the way networks function.
I learned a lot about networks
I learned how to effectively apply mathematics to the real world, and use math in a variety of settings.
Probability Theory, Random Walks, Social Networks, Herding, Network Effects, Cascades, Game Theory, GEPHI Software
I learned about networks, matrices, probability, etc
Learned how to create networks and link information.
I learned about the basics of how networks operate

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is boring and you don't learn anything, but it's really easy to get an A.

Strengths: flexible learning; world-class professor; material applicable to any academic focus
Weaknesses: lecture material unrelated to homework/exam tasks

Strengths: easy QR credit; exams were based on the homework which was helpful; TFs were helpful; final project was fun 

Weaknesses: lectures weren't very engaging and were confusing at times; while the TFs were helpful, I wish they had offered some office hours via zoom; overall, I don't really know what I got out of the class

Strengths: very easy!
Weakness: not much help if needed.

Strengths: the TAs provided good support for psets and the final project. 

Weaknesses: somewhat disorganized
Strengths: Flexible, hybrid format. Low-stress learning environment, interesting final project, fair exams and homework/PSets that reflected very accurately the material learned in the course
Low workload but lecture slides were not easy to read

The final project is a large strength as it gave students the ability to work together and produce a well thought out project. It was also helpful that we get more than one try on homework assignments. This allows students the ability to reflect and learn from their mistakes.

Strength: Easiest class at Yale
Weakness: Easiest class at Yale
Keep everything the same! Great class!
This course is great only if you need a QR gut. Literally less than an hour of work a week.
It could be better if the the professor gave constructive criticisms rather than calling his students stupid

Strengths - friendly TFs, good format of lecture/recorded lecture/lecture slides. Content well explained, easy to understand. Weakness - after the last problem sets have been submitted, there isn't much motivation to go to class, as you know you won't be examined on the content.
gephi was not explained well
Its a great work load

The strengths of this course are that you have the opportunity to correct your homework answers an unlimited amount of times until a certain deadline. This allows students to see where they went wrong: perhaps they had a minor arithmetic error, or incorrectly performed a 2 by 2 matrix equation. This then helps students be more cognizant of small mistakes during the midterm and final exams, both of which we can only submit once. The final exam and midterm exam are formatted exactly like the problem sets. A weakness of this course is that once you get to a certain point in the semester the lectures stop corresponding to the problem sets which can be a little confusing. Additionally, a lot of people solve their problem sets on their own by either teaching themselves or by trial and error. There are a generous amount of office hours available across multiple TFs, but a lot of students go through this course independent of TFs and the professor. This could be a strength or weakness depending on what your learning style and preferences are.
This course was very low stress and enjoyable.
Lectures are the most boring thing ever.
The class was very disorganized with many technical difficulties that made the content hard to understand. I sometimes struggled to see the connection between the lectures and the psets.
This course was good
The TA was very flexible and engaging and the availability of extra help sessions was a tremendous strength.

Strengths: low workload, interesting lectures, accomplished professor

Weaknesses: Easy to get lost in lecture

Assignments: Fair, Interesting, Relevant
Lectures: Engaging and Challenging
Project: Great Flexibility, Ability to Work With Data
I think the homework questions and the group project were helpful
Very interesting course.
It was a good class. Not too hard.

This course is a Yale staple-- an absolute gem. I attended class twice and never read the slides. The midterm is the psets VERBATUM with different numbers. It is also open laptop. Same thing for the final.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you're looking for a gut. Would not recommend if you're interested in learning anything.
If you need a QR credit, sure! If you're heavy on QR credits, would probably be a waste of time.
Yes. Easiest A I have ever gotten. Just complete the homework, double check your midterm and final, and join a group of 5 for your project and do something with data (sports, covid, census)
Best class at Yale
YES! It is a fun, easy and interesting class to take at Yale.
Yes for a gut. You dont learn anything though
I would recommend this course to any other humanities/non-STEM major who is interested in taking a useful and interesting math class.
Yes, everyone should take this class.
Definitely. It is a great QR credit for a non-math major.
Yes
Definitely! If you want an easier semester, definitely choose this class!
Yes, so easy.
I would recommend this class to anyone in need of a QR gut. You dont need to actually go to class, and the material is super easy to teach to yourself.
Yes, it is a straightforward class for non math people
Yes absolutely take this

If you are looking for a fifth class, or are looking for a QR credit but struggle with math, then this class is a good fit. If you have basic understanding of math and probabilities, this shouldn't be a problem. If you have more experience with math this class will be incredibly boring to you. Also, if you struggle in group projects I wouldn't recommend this class as you have to coordinate for a final project worth a lot of your grade.
maybe, its an easier course, but the topics covered in lecture were much more difficult than we needed for the assignments
Yes - you will get an A

Yes, if you are looking for a QR class, I would recommend this course. As long as you put forth effort into learning the material for the problem sets, the midterm and final exams will not be difficult for you. And while the final project requires more work than any other assignment for this course, you do get to work in a group of up to five, so the labor is divided.
Yes! Great way to fulfill the QR requirement and learn something new without stress. The TA's were great and responsive, as was Professor Coifman
Gut, but not an engaging class.
Yes

If you are non-stem and looking for a good qr credit, i'd recommend anything else: but if this is your last option then take it and be prepared to teach yourself material. TAs are really helpful but I don't think anyone knows exactly what the Professor wants, and that makes things very confusing
Of course! The class was manageable and engaging and my TF was extremely helpful.
Yes if you need an easy low workload class
In a heartbeat! This is a must-take class at Yale.
Yes, if you need a QR credit
Yes. Learned a lot of new information
Yes.
Easy QR credit but easy to not get much out of the course.
Yes!! Its a great class that is really catered towards non-STEM majors and a great 5th/6th class you can take.
Yes it was a good class
